item.dc:creator: Yana Proskurina
item.content:encoded:
The end of the week and weekend I spent working mostly on our bowling challenge.

It seemed ok in the beginning, code looked nice, then became heavier, then unreadable and then... I followed one of our coaches advice: "It is always fun to throw everything away and start from the beginning".

I had another idea on how to build it. The task became ok again, I wrote a nice engine, it all worked so nicely, that I decided to make an interface. That was not wise. I stopped sleeping at nights. I even came back to the first version of the code, but it made things even worse. I went to a long long walk to a park. And the next day again.

And then suddenly I had a solution. And it worked! And it involved only reasonable amount of code! And I even had some time to write this post!

But the lesson was learned - if you need an interface, think about it from the beginning.

item.dc:creator: Yana Proskurina
item.content:encoded:
Well, obviously I do not follow my plan...

At least I do not post here every day, but that is because I learn so many things simultaneously!

New knowledge for the last 3 days in few words:

MEAN stays for Mongo, Express, Angular and Node.

Node helps you to run your JS program using terminal, just print node <filename.js> in command line. If you type node in terminal you can play with JS the same way as you play with Ruby using irb (but I already got used to console and console.log()). It is not a server, but you can create one with it. And everything is in JS! So no need to switch from JS to Ruby (or another language) and back. An important thing about Node is that it is asynchronous, which makes it very effective. But you have to use callbacks for that, and it is not so straight forward in the beginning.

Express is something like Sinatra, but for Node JS. It seems easier and more intuitive, but may be it is because we already learned how to deal with Sinatra. For express template engine is not needed, it can handle html files directly, it is good for simple projects but for more complicated you can use Jade or ejs (they are like erb for ruby).

Mongo is a non SQL database, it stores information as JSON, and it seems a bit chaotic, but may be it is not, I just started to play with it.

And Angular... I am not sure yet. We will have the whole week dedicated to it, so I will write about it later.

Here is fantastic blog post on the topic.

item.dc:creator: Yana Proskurina
item.content:encoded:
It all started with Apple iPhone Software Update (to version 9.0). iPhone just stuck and did not want to move anywhere from the page 'slide to upgrade'.

Bugs that we make and catch during our learning process are not so epic of course, but sometimes an extra letter, a typo, lack of a dot or comma can easily ruin several hours of your life.

And now I got a flue bug, had to stay at home and decided to write this post.

So, how to find a bug?

For me, as a beginner, the easiest way to catch a bug is to print out everything that's going on in my code. I put a print (p or puts) statement before and after every line of my code, with a short explanation of what I am printing. Then I literally can read when and where a bug appears.

But there are better ways. For example, using pry or byebug.

Pry is very similar to irb, but has some extra features.
To use pry, first you need to install it using gem install pry or include gem 'pry' to your Gemfile and run bundle install.

Then you need to require pry in a file, where you want to find a bug, and print binding.pry before the place where you think the bug can be. When you run your program, it will stop at binding.pry point. And then you can print next lines in pry, receiving feedback on what is going on after each line.

Using byebug is similar. You install it using gem install byebug or include it into your Gemfile and run bundle install. Then you require byebug in a file anf print byebug in your file where you want your program to stop running. And then you can play with byebug, the same way as you play with irb or pry.

Bugs have no chances!

item.dc:creator: Yana Proskurina
item.content:encoded:
2 main things I learned today are:

  • how to structure your program,
  • how to deploy it to heroku.

The most difficult thing in structure is to create all necessary files and to connect them.

That is how a structure of our simple project looks like now.

project  
|___.git(folder, lots of things going on here)
|___Gemfile
|___Gemfile.lock
|___app
|   |__app.rb
|   |__data_mapper_setup.rb
|   |
|   |__models
|   |  |__first_model.rb
|   |  |__second_model.rb
|   |
|   |__views
|      |__index.erb
|      |__first_page
|         |__new.erb
|         |__old.erb
|
|___config.ru
|
|___.rspec
|___spec
    |___features
    |   |__first_feature_test_spec.spec
    |   |__second_feature_test_spec.spec
    |   |__third_feature_test_spec.spec
    |
    |___spec_helper.spec

Only three weeks of learning and I understand what each file is needed for! Well, I think I do.

App folder is all about our app, spec folder is about tests (same as .rspec file), .git is a folder with version control files, Gemfiles are about gems and config is to start our program.

Connecting all these files is a separate story. We use require or require_relative to connect files:

  • app.rb (our controller file for now) requires data_mapper_setup.rb, data_mapper_setup.rb requires model files (and that's how app.rb also knows about model files);
  • in .rspec we require spec_helper and spec_helper.rb in its turn requires app.rb and also data_mapper_setup.rb (only now while writing this post I realised I can do that instead of requiring data_mapper_setup from each test!);
  • in addition we require sinatra in app.rb, data mapper in data_mapper_setup, capybara and database cleaner in spec_helper.spec.

All clear and very logical, right?

In addition we had a very nice adventure to deploy our little bookmark manager program to heroku!

Heroku is super cool and simple, but when you use it for the first time and your program needs a database... it might be not so straightforward.

And here we had to learn the importance of environment in Sinatra. By pure coincidence I read "Jump start Sinatra" in a tube in the morning, and there was a little chapter called 'Environments'.

So, "... there are three predefined environments: development, production(when your app is live on the server), and test... To check what environment the app is running in, the helper methods production?, development? and test? will return true or false..."

We used this couple of times in Gemfile, like this: 

group :test do  
  gem 'rspec'
  gem 'capybara'
end

But I never paid attention.

What it actually means, is that depending on environment particular gems will or will not be used.

And when you use database it means, that depending on environment, path to a database will be different (when on local, database will be on your computer, when online using heroku database should be on ... heroku! Obvious, right?). So, we need to tell heroku to create database first, and in data_mapper_setup.rb we needed to indicate a path to a database depending on environment in which our program is running!

In our case:

  • for test environment we used database postgres://localhost/bookmark_manager_test
  • for development environment we used database postgres://localhost/bookmark_manager_development
  • and for production environment in heroku it is ENV['DATABASE_URL'].

To copy your database to heroku you do heroku run console and...

Well, I am not sure, will check it tomorrow.

And this is what we have so far.

Not much, but I am soooooooo proud!
